The Birth of Venus.passage: The Birth of Venus is a 1639 painting by Peter Paul Rubens. It is housed in the Kunsthistorisches Museum of Austria. The work is a pendant to Rubens's The Three Graces, which is also in the museum. The painting shows the goddess Venus, the Greek goddess of love, as a baby being nursed by the goddess Juno. The work is an allegory of the triumph of love over death. The painting is also known as the Venus of Urbino.

The Arnolfini Portrait.passage: The Arnolfini Portrait, also known as Portrait of a Man with a Blue Chaperon, is a painting by the Early Netherlandish painter Jan van Eyck. It was painted around 1434, and is housed in the National Gallery in London. The sitter is identified as Giovanna da Piacenza, the wife of Giovanni di Niccolò Arnolfini. It is the only known oil painting of a Northern European woman from the early 15th century. The painting was commissioned by Giovanni di Niccolò Arnolfini (1400-1464), a wealthy silk merchant from Lucca, who had married into a wealthy Florentine family. The couple lived in the prosperous Dutch city of Bruges, which was an important trading centre and the largest city in Flanders. The Arnolfini were among the most prominent members of their community, and were friends with the leading artists of the day. The painting was probably completed in 1434, shortly after the marriage. The painting was probably the culmination of a commission by the Arnolfinis. The Arnolfinis were prosperous members of the Bruges art world, and the painting was likely a gift for Giovanni's brother Giacomo, who was a successful goldsmith.

The Starry Night.passage: The Starry Night is a painting by Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh. It is among the most recognized paintings in the world and one of the most recognizable paintings by Vincent van Gogh. The Starry Night depicts a view of the nighttime sky in the south of France, seen from the window of the asylum room where van Gogh was living at the time. It depicts the view outside the window of the asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, painted with oil paint and a palette knife on a sheet of Arches paper. Van Gogh began the painting on 23 January 1889 and continued working on it until he died in July 1890. He worked on it in fits and starts, completing some parts and then abandoning it. It was left unfinished at his death and remained so until 1927, when it was purchased by the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The painting is one of the most recognizable artworks of the 20th century, and it was voted the most popular artwork in the world in a 2004 survey by BBC News Online and the British Museum. In 2011, it was named as one of the top 100 most important paintings of all time by the Artcyclopedia project. The Raft of the Medusa.passage: The Raft of the Medusa, also known as The Wreck of the Medusa, is an oil painting by Théodore Géricault, created in 1819. It shows the aftermath of a shipwreck, with only a few survivors clinging to the wreckage of a raft. It is one of the most famous paintings in history, and was a major influence on the Romantic movement. The Raft of the Medusa was commissioned by Louis-Philippe for the Paris Opéra Garnier, but the King abdicated and fled the country before it was finished. Géricault was left without payment, and the painting was seized by creditors. It was eventually purchased by the Louvre in 1846. The painting is currently on view in the Louvre's Musée du Louvre. It is one of the most visited paintings in the museum. The painting shows a raft of the French frigate Medusa, which sank in 1816 during the French campaign in Algiers. Géricault was a member of a group of French artists sent to document the campaign, but the ship was wrecked in a storm and only a few survivors were rescued. The raft was found drifting in the ocean, and the few survivors were clinging to its wreckage.

The Murder of Gonzago.passage: The Murder of Gonzago is a painting by Peter Paul Rubens, completed between 1607 and 1610 and now in the Museo del Prado in Madrid, Spain. It is one of the masterpieces of the artist's early Baroque style. It was commissioned by the Duke of Lerma, and is thought to have been intended to be hung in his house in Aranjuez. It shows the murder of Gonzago, a Moor by the name of Gonzalo Guerrero, who was beheaded in 1591 by the Spanish Inquisition for the crime of heresy. The painting is one of the first examples of a Baroque tondo, a circular painting that depicts a scene in an interior, and is a forerunner to the trompe l'oeil paintings of the 17th century. The work shows Gonzalo Guerrero being beheaded by a sword, while his wife kneels in despair, holding their dead child. A dog looks on, as if it were the only witness. The painting was commissioned by the Duke of Lerma, and is thought to have been intended to be hung in his house in Aranjuez. It is one of Rubens's most famous paintings, and is considered one of his masterpieces. It was first recorded in the collection of the Duke of Lerma in 1703, but it is not certain that the work was the one commissioned by the duke.

The Thinker.passage: The Thinker is a marble statue of an ancient Greek man, created by the Italian sculptor Gian Lorenzo Bernini in 1650. It is a representation of the Roman philosopher and poet Cicero, who is shown deep in thought, his right hand supporting his head and his left hand holding a scroll with his writings. The statue is one of the most famous works of sculpture in the world. The original statue, commissioned by Louis XIV of France for the Palace of Versailles, was placed in the center of a round reflecting pool in the main courtyard of the palace. The fountain was designed by the French architect André Le Nôtre. The statue is made of travertine marble. In 1682, Louis XIV had the statue removed from the fountain and placed in a small room in the palace. He had the room lined with red velvet and had a small desk placed in front of it. He would sit in the room and contemplate, while holding court from behind the desk. The room was called the Cabinet du Roi ("King's Cabinet"). The room was used in this way until 1698 when Louis XIV had it moved to the Palace of Fontainebleau. There it was placed in front of the King's bedchamber. The room was redecorated in the rococo style. In 1752, the statue was removed from the room and placed in a gallery at the Palace of Versailles.

Peter Paul Rubens.passage: Born in Siegen, the Netherlands, Peter Paul Rubens (1577–1640) was the leading Flemish painter of his era. He was a prolific artist, with a large number of pupils, who spread his style over much of Europe. Rubens was a master of the art of painting, but he is also regarded as a great art collector and connoisseur. He was a prolific artist who painted over 600 known works. the Kunsthistorisches Museum.passage: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna, also known as the Kunstkammer, Kunstgewerbe- und Sammlungshaus, or the Imperial and Royal Picture Gallery, was a museum in Vienna, Austria, dedicated to art and antiquities from prehistory to the early modern period. It was the first museum in the world to be devoted exclusively to the history of art. The Kunsthistorisches Museum is located at the Hofburg Palace in the Innere Stadt district, and has the largest art collection in the world, with more than 20,000 objects.

the National Gallery.passage: The Gallery has been open to the public since 1831 and is free of charge. It houses the national collection of Western European painting, covering the period 1250 to 1900, and the National collection of Western European sculpture, dating from the 12th to 19th centuries. The collection of the National Gallery has been expanded many times through gifts and purchases, including works by Claude Monet, Paul Cézanne, Vincent van Gogh, and Pablo Picasso. the Museo del Prado.passage: The Museo del Prado (English: "Prado Museum") is a museum in Madrid, Spain, housing the national art collection of Spain. It was founded in 1819 on the orders of King Ferdinand VII on the basis of the former Real Armería, a royal armoury, which he had inherited from his father Charles IV of Spain. Hieronymus Bosch.passage: Hieronymus Bosch (/ˈbiːɵˌnoʊməs bɔːʃ/;[note 1] c. 150 – c. 1516) was a Dutch painter from the Northern Netherlands. He is best known for his triptych altarpiece "The Garden of Earthly Delights", and for his use of surreal and nightmarish imagery. His work has been influential to many subsequent artists, including Salvador Dalí and the English poet William Blake. Bosch was born in's-Hertogenbosch, now in the Netherlands but then in the Duchy of Brabant. He was a child of poor parents. The family lived near St. Janskerk in the Oude Groenmarkt. He was baptized as "Jeroom" (Gerard) but later took the name "Jeroom" (Jerome). His birthdate is unknown, but is estimated to be around 150. He was a student of the painter and glass painter Jan van Scorel. In 1515, he moved to's-Hertogenbosch to work as a painter and stained glass designer. He married a local woman, and had at least one son. He was a contemporary of Pieter Bruegel the Elder.

Edvard Munch.passage: Edvard Munch (Norwegian: [ˈedvɑrɟ (ˌ)mʏntʃ]; Norwegian pronunciation: [ˌedvɑːrɟ (ˌ)mʊntʃ]; Norwegian Bokmål: [ˈedvɑːrɟ (mʏntʃ)]) (30 May 1863 – 23 January 1944) was a Norwegian painter and a pivotal figure in the Symbolist movement in painting. His best-known and most reproduced work is The Scream (1893), often regarded as the most famous artwork produced in Scandinavia. He is also known for his paintings The Sick Child (1889) and Madonna (1894–1902).

Arches.passage:
Arches National Park, in the U.S. state of Utah, is a United States National Park Service unit that preserves the natural and cultural resources of a unique and diverse landscape of red rock canyons, fins, and freestanding arches. Arches is one of the most visited national parks in the United States, receiving approximately 4.4 million visitors in 2017. The park's most popular feature is its 275 sandstone arches, which range in size from a few feet to the tallest, Delicate Arch, at. The park also features nearly 2,000 natural stone arches, several large rock towers, and numerous natural stone bridges. The park is named for the numerous arches, some of which are the largest and most spectacular in the world. The park is located in southeastern Utah, approximately 40 miles (64 km) east of Moab, and 60 miles (97 km) south of Salt Lake City. Arches is the second-most visited national park in the United States, behind the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The park covers 1,300 square miles (3,400 km2), making it larger than the U.
S. state of Rhode Island.

France.passage: France (i/fɛˈrɑːns/; French: [fʁɑ̃s]; Italian: [fra̯ns]; German: [fʁɑ̃s]; Spanish: [fra̯nθ]; Portuguese: [frentʃo]), officially the French Republic, is a country with territory in Western Europe and several overseas regions and territories. The European, or metropolitan, area of France extends from the Mediterranean Sea to the English Channel and the North Sea, and from the Rhine to the Atlantic Ocean. Overseas France include French Guiana on the South American continent and several island territories in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian oceans. France's territory has an area of, and as of 2019 its population is 67.5 million, ranking it as the world's fifth-most populous country. It is a unitary semi-presidential republic with the capital in Paris, the country's largest city and main cultural and commercial centre. Other major urban centres include Marseille, Lyon, Lille, Nice, Toulouse and Bordeaux. France is a unitary state made up of 83 departments, including its overseas territories and collectivities.

Vincent van Gogh.passage: Vincent Van Gogh was a Dutch Post-impressionist painter. He produced over 2,100 artworks, including 800 oil paintings, 350 watercolors and sketches, and 150 drawings. He is best known for his sunflower paintings, as well as for his self-portraits, and for expressing himself through his art. Van Gogh is among the most recognized and widely collected artists, and he is regarded by many as the greatest painter of the Post-impressionist era. He was born in 1853 in Zundert, in the southern Netherlands, to a Protestant family of modest means. He was the eldest of seven children, four of whom died in early childhood. Van Gogh was largely self-taught and developed an affinity for Japanese art, which profoundly influenced him. He worked as an art dealer and teacher, and he was also an art collector. He lived in France and Belgium, where he had a difficult time finding acceptance in the art world. In 1880, he moved to London, where he hoped to improve his chances of success, but was unsuccessful and became increasingly lonely. His mental health declined, and he was admitted to an asylum. He died in 1890 of a gunshot wound, possibly a suicide, and was buried in an unmarked grave in Auvers-sur-Oise, France. In the years after his death, his work began to attract widespread attention.

Spain.passage: Spain, officially the Kingdom of Spain, is a country in southwestern Europe, largely situated on the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered to the north and northeast by France, to the east and southeast by Portugal, to the south and southwest by Andorra and Morocco, and to the northwest by the Bay of Biscay and the Cantabrian Sea. The territory of modern Spain is composed of several different regions. The population is about 47 million, and the capital and largest city is Madrid. Spain is one of the leading economic powers in Europe, with a developed market economy and a large, diversified service sector. It is a member of the European Union, the Eurozone and the Council of Europe.

the Österreichische Galerie Belvedere.passage: Österreichische Galerie Belvedere is an art gallery in Vienna, Austria that houses the largest collection of Baroque and Rococo art in the world. Vienna.passage: Vienna (German: "Wien" (listen)) is the capital and largest city of Austria and one of the nine states of Austria. Vienna is Austria's primary city and national capital. The city proper has an estimated population of 1,200,000 within the city limits, while its urban area (which includes the municipalities of Döbling, Liesing and Albern) is home to a grand total of 2,200,000 people, ranking it the second largest city in Austria and the fourth-largest city in the European Union (EU). Vienna is Austria's leading economic centre, and one of the largest financial centers in Europe after London, Paris, and Frankfurt.

Gian Lorenzo Bernini.passage: Gian Lorenzo Bernini (Italian: [dʒa̞ˈnloʁno bernaˈni];[n 1] c. 1598 – 1680) was an Italian Baroque sculptor, architect, and painter. His output ranged from the large-scale bronze decoration of the Cornaro Chapel (1621) and Ecstasy of St Theresa (1645–52), to the delicate marble sculptures of the Apollo and Daphne (1622–25) and the Torso Belvedere (1621), to the colossal marble sculptures of David (1623–24) and Saint Longinus (1630–35), to the architecture of the colonnade of St Peter's Square and the colonnade surrounding the Basilica of Saint Peter (1657–66). He is widely considered to be the greatest sculptor of the 17th century.

qae_pairs.question: How many years after the death of Gian Lorenzo Bernini did the Torso Belvedere come to be?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Torso Belvedere was completed in 1621, four years after the death of Gian Lorenzo Bernini.
